results.title: Breathless = A bout de souffle [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Jean-Luc Godard, Georges de Beauregard, Imperia, Productions Georges de Beauregard and Societe Nouvelle de Cinematographie
results.brief_description: When the “young Turks” from the journal Cahiers du Cinema began making films in the late fifties, they revolutionised cinema by celebrating the look and attitudes of American pop-culture (B-movies, rock and roll) while infusing their own films with the uncertainties of a then distinctly European intellectual scrutiny. In “Breathless” a young hood kills a cop and goes on the run in Paris, hiding at his girlfriend’s flat until she betrays him. That’s life. Kiss-kiss, bang-bang. Playful, cool, name-dropping and audacious the film is true to its title, furiously exploring the possibilities of cinema while acknowledging its aesthetic debt to the low-budget films of Hollywood’s B-directors. Godard’s film remains the most influential of the French New Wave, and as the decade was to progress, Vietnam, Algiers and Maoism were to demand of him a more intellectually dense cinema. But in “Breathless” he is still the cheeky precocious brat, thumbing his nose at the world and inventing a new kind of film. From an original treatment by Francois Trauffaut, and with Claude Charbrol as artist and technical adviser. With Jean-Paul Belmondo and Jean Seberg.

results.title: The Last Wave [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Peter Weir, James McElroy, Hal McElroy and Ayer Productions
results.brief_description: In this atmospheric mystery thriller a young Sydney lawyer, while defending Aborigines against a murder charge, is troubled by dreams and is drawn into an underground world, the intimations of an ancient civilization. Step by step a series of apparently random occurences assume a disturbing pattern. The city becomes a facade for a place of ancient ritual. Cast includes Richard Chamberlain and David Gulpilil and features photography by Russell Boyd. Features a digitally restored soundtrack.

results.title: Dark victory
results.creator_credit: Edmund Goulding, First National Pictures and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: Dark victory was nominated for three Oscars in 1940 including Best Picture and Best Actress for Bette Davis. Davis and the film lost out in that year on both counts to “Gone with the wind”. In “Dark victory” Davis plays Judith Traherne, a beautiful young Long Island socialite, without a care in the world until she discovers she is suffering from a potentially fatal brain tumour. Her surgeon offers temporary hope with an operation prolonging her life and simultaneously brings love to Traherne’s life for the first time. One of four collaborations between director and star, “Dark victory” is a typical Hollywood melodrama of the 30s that rises above the ordinary, thanks to the compelling presence of Davis. Davis portrays Traherne as a beguiling, earnest, and impetuous woman, reluctantly facing her own mortality. Humphrey Bogart stars as an Irish horse trainer holding a candle for Traherne’s affection. Future president of the United States Ronald Reagan has a minor role in the film as a playboy socialite. “Dark victory” is reflective of the strong period that Bette Davis’ career was at in the late 1930s and 40s when she enjoyed studio backing and public acclaim.

results.title: The American president
results.creator_credit: Rob Reiner, Castle Rock Entertainment and Universal Pictures
results.brief_description: Rob Reiner (A Few good men, Misery, When Harry met Sally) directs this comedy about a fictional American President, who has more than a passing resemblance to President Clinton. Written by Aaron Sorkin (The West Wing, A Few good men) “The American President” is a light-hearted romantic comedy about life in The Oval Office. Democrat president Andrew Shepherd (Michael Douglas) is a widower three years into his term with a 63% approval rating, when he meets the intelligent, attractive Sydney Wade (Annette Bening), an environmental issues lobbyist. Shepherd woos and starts to date Wade, who reciprocates his interest. With an election looming, problems arise when Shepard’s political enemies exploit the situation seeking to hamper his re-election by depicting him as a radical. The private life of Shepherd is scrutinised by the media, raising questions of public responsibility verses ownership of a private life for those living in the media glare. The film is most enjoyable when it takes a behind the scenes look at the machinations of the hectic, compartmentalised life of a president. Also starring Richard Dreyfuss, Martin Sheen and Michael J. Fox, Samantha Mathis, John Mahoney and David Paymer.

results.title: Two women = La Ciociara (Special edition)
results.creator_credit: Vittorio De Sica, Carlo Ponti, Societe Generale de Cinematographie, Cocinor and Compagnia Cinematografica Champion Films Marceau
results.brief_description: Two women is the story of Cesira and Rosetta, mother and daughter, living in Rome and running a grocery store under grim World War II conditions. After a raid, Cesira, a beautiful widow who is propositioned at every turn, decides to relocate them to the rural village where she was born. Cesira idealises her innocent teenage daughter, attempting to shield her from the reality of war crimes and the potential danger (in particular rape) that the two face. Michele (Jean-Paul Belmondo) an idealist, who is horrified by the pettiness of the villagers, falls in love with Cesira. A love triangle forms between mother, daughter and Michele as war closes in around the village. Adapted from the Italian novel by Alberto Moravia, “Two women” effectively displays the randomness of war that can turn an individual’s fate to terror and the deprivations that reduce simple acts of kindness to bitter transactions. Sophia Loren won an Academy Award for her portrayal of Cesira, an uncommon accolade at that time. This is the dubbed version with Sophia Loren dubbing her own voice. Directed by Vittoria De Sica (The Bicycle Thief, Umberto D., Marriage - Italian style).

results.title: Among giants
results.creator_credit: Sam Miller, Stephen Garrett, YMPA, BBC Film Unit, Kudos, Capitol Films and Fox Searchlight Pictures
results.brief_description: From the writer of “The Full monty”, Simon Beaufoy, comes “Among giants”, a tale set in Sheffield, England about a group of unemployed blue-collar workers who take on odd jobs to make ends meet. The latest of these high risk ventures is an unofficial contract to paint miles of power towers on the remote and beautiful Yorkshire Moors. The group are an eclectic mix of ageing hippies and adrenalin seeking rock climbers, very laddish in their encounters with one another. Into this all male crew enters Gerry (Rachel Griffiths) a feisty, fearless, mountain climbing Australian backpacker, who upsets the working life and social order of the group. Gerry falls for her boss Ray (Pete Postlethwaite) fuelling problems for both of them with his ex-wife, and with his best friend, Steven. Tensions rise as racing against the clock, the crew strives to complete the job, whilst Ray and Gerry struggle to resolve the status of their relationship. Billed as a romantic comedy, the film is situated in the tradition of light hearted tales of the woes of English working class life.

results.title: Southern comfort
results.creator_credit: Walter Hill, David Giler, Cinema Group, EMI/Parlophone and Phoenix Films
results.brief_description: Louisiana 1973 - a squad from the Louisiana National Guard, together for a weekend reconnaissance exercise in the Louisiana Bayou, are about to experience the fight of their lives against an unexpected enemy. Eight men make up the squad and within this group exists a volatility which is about to tear them apart. Their own private unintentional war begins when they decide to steal three canoes from a Cajun campsite. This action results in unfortunate consequences when trigger-happy Private Stuckey fires blanks at some local Cajuns who have spotted them paddling off in the canoes. Retaliation and revenge follows and the battle for survival begins. Filmed in the Louisiana swamps, director Walter Hill (Crossroads, 48 Hours, Last man standing) has succeeded in creating an atmospheric environ which heightens the tension and adds to the ever-increasing state of paranoia. Surreal and disturbing, “Southern comfort” bears a similarity to “Deliverance” where the environment and the local people become the focus of the story. As in “Deliverance”, music too plays an important part and it is the brilliant Ry Cooder who has composed and arranged the music for this film with cinematography by Andrew Laszlo. Cast includes Keith Carradine, Powers Boothe, Fred Ward, Peter Coyote, Carlos Brown.

results.title: What's up Doc?
results.creator_credit: Peter Bogdanovich, Warner Bros Pictures and Saticoy Productions
results.brief_description: Taking its cues from the classic 1930s screwball comedies of Howard Hawks and Preston Sturges, “What’s up Doc” is most reminiscent (more or less a remake) of “Bringing up Baby” (Hawks, 1938). Barbra Streisand plays the flighty university student Judy Maxwell, who has trouble deciding which course she is in, creating chaos wherever she goes with her free-spirited presence. After spying nerdy musicologist Howard Bannister (Ryan O’Neal), Judy decides they are a perfect match and sets her romantic sights on him. As per the genre, Howard has an equally nebbish fiancee, who is of course but a minor obstacle in the course of true love. The film scores lots of laughs with a series of mixed up suitcases, missing jewels, an extensive chase scene, and romantic interludes. “What’s up Doc?” manages a successful mix of rapid fire dialogue, physical comedy and charming lead performances, which made it one of the big hits of 1972, the second in a row for director Peter Bogdanovich (The Last Picture show, Paper moon, The Cat’s meow). Features several songs by Barbra Streisand.

results.title: One deadly summer = L'Ete Meurtrier
results.creator_credit: Jean Becker, Christine Beyout, TF1 Films productions, Societe Nouvelle de Cinematographie and CAPAC
results.brief_description: Isabelle Adjani plays Elle, a fiery nineteen-year-old woman who moves to a small provincial French town with her introverted German born mother and reclusive disabled father. Elle is a confident woman who wantonly displays her sexy body and soon has every man in town captivated. Alain Souchon plays Pin Pon, a mechanic who falls into an obsession with Elle, and agonizes over invalidated rumours of other men’s conquests of her. Motivated by revenge, Elle easily draws Pin Pon into her orbit and soon moves in with him, despite the disapproval of his pious mother. Through a series of flashbacks it is revealed that twenty years earlier, in the post war period, Elle’s mother was brutally gang raped by several French deliverymen. Elle, tortured by issues of her parentage, is driven to avenge her mother’s rape but is also stirred by secrets from her own past that exacerbate her increasingly unstable mental condition. The switching of first person narration allows for multiple viewpoints to be appreciated by the viewer. This is a tragedy about vengeance, obsessive behaviour and neuroses. (Awards: Adjani won a Cesar for Best supporting actress, 1983). In French with English subtitles.

Elle is a confident woman who wantonly displays her sexy body and soon has every man in town captivated. Alain Souchon plays Pin Pon, a mechanic who falls into an obsession with Elle, and agonizes over invalidated rumours of other men’s conquests of her. Motivated by revenge, Elle easily draws Pin Pon into her orbit and soon moves in with him, despite the disapproval of his pious mother. Through a series of flashbacks it is revealed that twenty years earlier, in the post war period, Elle’s mother was brutally gang raped by several French deliverymen. Elle, tortured by issues of her parentage, is driven to avenge her mother’s rape but is also stirred by secrets from her own past that exacerbate her increasingly unstable mental condition. The switching of first person narration allows for multiple viewpoints to be appreciated by the viewer. This is a tragedy about vengeance, obsessive behaviour and neuroses. (Awards: Adjani won a Cesar for Best supporting actress, 1983). In French with English subtitles.
description_for_label: Isabelle Adjani plays Elle, a fiery nineteen-year-old woman who moves to a small provincial French town with her introverted German born mother and reclusive disabled father. Elle is a confident woman who wantonly displays her sexy body and soon has every man in town captivated. Alain Souchon plays Pin Pon, a mechanic who falls into an obsession with Elle, and agonizes over invalidated rumours of other men’s conquests of her. Motivated by revenge, Elle easily draws Pin Pon into her orbit and soon moves in with him, despite the disapproval of his pious mother. Through a series of flashbacks it is revealed that twenty years earlier, in the post war period, Elle’s mother was brutally gang raped by several French deliverymen. Elle, tortured by issues of her parentage, is driven to avenge her mother’s rape but is also stirred by secrets from her own past that exacerbate her increasingly unstable mental condition. The switching of first person narration allows for multiple viewpoints to be appreciated by the viewer. This is a tragedy about vengeance, obsessive behaviour and neuroses. (Awards: Adjani won a Cesar for Best supporting actress, 1983). In French with English subtitles.

results.title: Blood and black lace [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Mario Bava, Massimo Patrizi, Alfredo Mirabile, Allied Artists Pictures and Emmepi Cinematografica
results.brief_description: Set in a glamorous Italian fashion house, Mario Bava’s garish ‘stalk and slash’ thriller is elevated by it’s vibrant colour design and lush film score. The film’s lean plot jolts into action when a young model is brutally murdered one evening, leaving behind a diary which basically incriminates everyone around her. Soon enough a masked killer is after this vital piece of evidence while murdering (in gruesome fashion, including death by red hot iron) anyone who has been in contact with it. Being the fashion world, everyone has something to hide and is therefore a potential suspect. Recognized as one of the earliest examples of the Italian ‘giallo’ thrillers (‘giallo’ or ‘yellow’ refers to the colour of the covers for a series of pulp Italian crime novels), “Blood and black lace” uses colour, in particular the colour red in startling ways. Most memorable are the eerie red mannequins that populate the fashion house and a fabulous credit sequence incorporating the principal cast. Not to be matched however is the inventive murders Bava dreams up for his hapless victims, a novel devise that eventually became the standard for the American slasher films of the 80’s and beyond. Also known as: Six women for the murderer, Fashion house of death. Cast includes: Eva Bartok, Cameron Mitchell, Leo Kruger, Mary Arden, Arianna Gorini.
